Thank you for supporting us during this incredibly challenging time.Whilst I have every sympathy with Scottish fishermen and the problems with the EU since Brexit, perhaps it is time they looked at the possibility of selling to the home market. I see Loch Fyne langoustines are sent to the EU but, living fairly close to Loch Fyne, I don#t seem to be able to purchase the product locally.I am sure UK supermarkets would be only too happy to sell, crabs, lobsters and langoustines provided by Scottish fishermen but it seems they would prefer to supply the EU rather than the home market.Fishing boats enter Campbeltown Loch regularly but there is no local supply of their catch as this is transported #up the road# as soon as it is landed.I just suggest that supplying the UK market is maybe a way out of the continual problems with our #friendly# neighbours who seem hell bent on putting continual obstacles in the way of sensible trading partnerships.Keith Abendroth, Campbeltown.I grew up in Peninver and have been hiking on the hills around the Rest and Be Thankful many times, all year round. My initial thought a few years ago was that the best solution to the problem of landslides on the Rest was building avalanche tunnels like there are on the A at Lochcarron but there is practically zero ground to build on on the downhill side of the A.The big catch-pits along the uphill side of the road do seem to work but, in the long-term, removing the unstable soil and planting lots of trees and shrubs on the rest of the hillside to hold it in place, might be the best solution.Rather than replace the road through the Rest and Be Thankful with a new route through another glen or to continue trying to stop an unstable hillside from obeying the laws of gravity, how much would it cost to remove all the soil in these watercourses which regularly slide Maybe cost-wise removing the unstable soil from the Rest would be cheaper # and quicker  # than building a whole new road If there is a landslide in a watercourse, it weakens the soil directly above it so that will slide next, followed by the soil above it, etc. The bedrock at the Rest is only a couple of feet below the surface so removing the soil in gullies liable to slide after rain might be a lot cheaper than building a new road through another glen.For a permanent solution, perhaps close off the road from Ardgartan to the Lochgoilhead junction for six months in the winter, pipe water from Loch Restil to the top of the gullies prone to sliding # at the base of the first exposed bedrock high up the gullies # let the water run for three or four months, and hydraulically remove all the loose soil, then in the spring shovel all the accumulated debris of the other side of the road It would mean short-term inconvenience for a lot of people but it might save a lot of money, time, and perhaps lives, in the long-term.Harry Hood, New Hampshire, USA. As children and young peopleto being home-schooled due to the new lockdown, there is no doubt that this will have a continued detrimental impact on mental health and wellbeing.As a coalition, we applaud the Scottish Government’s greater investment in mental health services. However, a view we share with other organisations, is that this investment is simply not sufficient.Mental health services were already under immense strain prior to Covid-, with children waiting considerable s of time for support. Recent statistics from December, for example, point to the fact that more than , children have been waiting over a year for treatment.This pandemic will only serve to make matters even worse as services deal with a backlog of those already suffering from mental health problems, added to which will be those who have developed problems over the course of lockdown.What is needed is a national crusade, delivering signicant investment in the public, private and third sectors to deliver adequate mental health support, both during and as we recover from Covid-. We must also use this as an opportunity to radically transform our mental health services, both for now and for the future, refocusing on prevention and early intervention.In the meantime, we would urge those children and their families who feel they need help not to hold back and look to get the support they need.The Scottish Children’s Services Coalition: Kenny Graham, Falkland House School Lynn Bell, LOVE Learning Stephen McGhee, Spark of Genius Niall Kelly, Young Foundations.The serious neurological condition Myalgic Encephalomylitiswill sadly be all too familiar to some of your readers at least , children and adults in Scotland live with ME, also diagnosed as chronic fatigue syndrome .Many face barriers in accessing health and social care services that meet their needs, and some professionals still don’t understand the impact of ME and its symptoms.UK charity Action for ME is trying to change this by offering people with ME across Scotland one-to-one advocacy, via phone and email, to help them be heard, understand their rights and access support.We want to expand this much-needed service, and are seeking enthusiastic volunteers in Scotland who can make the most of our online advocate training programme to develop their skills, gain valuable experience, and help improve the lives of vulnerable people with ME, all from home.Anyone who is interested in finding out more can call , emailor visit our website– we would love to hear from good listeners who can spare two hours a week.Alice Cranston, advocacy coordinator, Action for ME.

I’m anticipating an end to the pandemic – coming out of the gloom. And there have been many episodes in le in which I’ve lived in the hope of emerging through the other side of the dark night. I thank God for the hope he gives me. But, how do we know when the darkness of night has ended In a rabbinic school, a very old rabbi posed a clever question to his young students: #When can it be said that night truly ends and the day begins  When is that moment when from darkness there comes light, when it can really be said the gloom has passed and brightness is here #The first student, still a bit immature, replied: #Well, it’s when it says so on the internet.#The rabbi smiled and told him: #That’s not what I mean.#The next student said: #It’s when you can distinguish sheep from goats, because in the dark they look very similar, but when light appears they can be told apart.#The rabbi told him it was a wiser answer, but not the one.The third student said: #When you can tell the fig tree and palm tree apart.#This interested the rabbi, but, no, this wasn’t it. The rabbi askedthere were any other ideas, but there weren’t. So he told them the answer: #It is when you look at another person and do not see a stranger but a brother or sister this is when know the night has ended and the day begins.#Father Tony Wood, Saint Kieran#s Catholic Church, Campbeltown.

Thank you for supporting us during this incredibly challenging time.The way we do business with the EU has changed. Many firms are already adapting to the new rules and making plans for the future. If your business has not introduced changes, it is not too late. But you must act now! This is what you need to do.New rules for doing business with Europe are in place and you must act now to continue trading with the continent. The UK Government has already minimised disruption, staggering border control changes. But you must #·         Make customs declarations when exporting goods to the EU – couriers, freight forwarders or customs agents can help.·         Ensure you have an EORI number starting with GB, check new rules for importing and exporting, and that your goods meet origin rules.·         If exporting, you need to check the EU business you’re exporting to is also ready. If you’re due to travel to the EU for work, you may need a visa or work permit.·         If you want to hire from outside the UK, including the EU, you must be a Home Office licenced sponsor under the UK’s new points-based immigration system.MAKE CHANGESTrading with Europe has changed.  So, to avoid disruption to your company’s operations, you need to make changes too.Visit the gov.uk transition site and use the Brexit checker tool to access personalised actions for your company.TEAMWORK IS VITALPLAYDALE PLAYGROUNDS Teamwork is the secret of UK transition success, according to an award-winning Cumbrian family business. “There are UK Government website resources,” confirms Barry Leahey, MD of ninth generation family firm Playdale Playgrounds. “There’s also the Department for International Trade. The CBI has an excellent website, there’s lots of assistance on there, as does the IOD and local chambers. “We’ve accessed all these great resources to create an action sheet. All the information is out there. “You’ve got to do your research but you only have to do it once,” continues the business boss who “sells fun all over the world”, his -plus workforce supplying  countries. “In the first weeks of January we’ve got goods on the road. What we’re finding is our European partners, who we’ve prompted, have also been breaking old habits and creating new ones “I think everything’s going smoother than we expected.”‘IT’S NOT A HASSLE’BRADFORDS BAKERSCompanies still preparing for the new rules should not “bury their heads in the sand.”“It will sort itself out. You have to deal with things you’ve never dealt with before. But, once you’ve put the systems in place, it’s not as big a hassle as you think,” assures James McGoldrick.Bradfords successfully supplies luxury hampers, baskets and gt sets to the EU and beyond thanks to following UK Government guidelines.“The UK Government website was very good, it took you through everything,” he confirms, reassuring other operators who must now swtly follow suit that “these things are all quite quick actually.”‘YOU’RE NOT ALONE’NAISSANCE“We’re all in this together” reassures a South Wales company chief whose family firm is successfully trading under the new rules.Two thirds of Neath-based Naissance’s essential oil sales are with “important trading partners” within the EU.“My advice is don’t bury your head in the sand,” advises Jem Skelding, who employs over  staff.“We’re all trying to figure this out. If you are struggling with it, or finding it dficult, you’re not alone, there’s help and advice.“The UK Government website has lots of useful information.“The light at the end of the tunnel is we’re seeing progress, things are improving. Try to see the positives.” Jem stresses urgent action from business is required regarding VAT, GDPR, EU workers, duty deferment, terms and conditions, contracts, customs declarations and agents as well as Economic Operators Registration and Identication numbers.“As things settle down, new opportunities will undoubtedly present themselves.”gdpr_consent "

Thank you for supporting us during this incredibly challenging time.Last week saw the conclusion of the serialisation of Campbeltown soldier Gunner Neil MacLean#s previously unpublished prisoner of war diary.Gunner MacLean was captured in June  following the st Highland Division’s surrender at St Valéry-en-Caux during the Second World War.A copy of his diary, several photographs and a poem, below, which was written during his time as a prisoner of war, were supplied to the Courier by Neil’s son Calum, who knew nothing of their existence until after his father died aged .On the th day of June with old Blighty so gay,We were then taken prisoners, I’m sure you all know,We all did our best, we all want you to know,The above photograph shows Neil and the men of the Campbeltown-based  Anti-Tank Battery, which served alongside the st Highland Division in France in , at a reunion in Campbeltown around .Many of the battery members, all from the Territorial Army, were captured when the majority of the st Highland Division surrendered to the German forces, but some made it back to Britain and were later sent to the Far East.This photo shows, back row, from left: Malcolm Campbell, Robbie McArthur, John McNaughton, Duncan McIntyre, Duncan McIntyre, John McKinlay.Second back row: Jock McKay, John Shaw, John Robertson, Duncan McLaughlin, Alex McKinven, Alex Robertson, John Mathieson, James Morrans, Willie Cook, Hamish Lynn, Jacky McKinven, Dougie McDonald, Neil MacLean, Davie Finn, John McNaughton, Jimmy Finn, John McCallum, Andy Mathieson, Dan McKinven, Sergeant Major John McDougall, Willie McCormick.Second from front row: Willie Anderson, John McMillan, James Shaw, Finlay Huie, Hamish Morrans, Captain George Lewis, Major Macalister-Hall.Front row: Charlie Morrison, Neil Gillies, Duncan McCallum, Jimmy Cunningham, Berty Cook, Jimmy McIvor.

The news was welcomed by the prospective Conservative candidate for Argyll and Bute, Mr Ralph Leishman.He told the Courier: ‘This is a definite step forward and knocks on the head suggestions that the Scottish Office is totally opposed to CalMac as the operator on this route.’Scottish Office reservations are believed to centre on proposals to use the MV Claymore on the route. Thank you for supporting us during this incredibly challenging time.By Jingo, Keith Abendroth has some brass neck in blaming the catastrophe facing Scottish fishing businesses on the dastardly EU. His solution is even more batty.Driven by resentment and sepia-tinted post-Empire English nationalism, cloaked in talk of Britain and the UK, the Tories have jemmied the UK out of the world’s largest and most successful single market.Having placed the UK as a #third country# outside the EU, alongside Somalia and Kazakhstan, it is not the EU to blame for the barriers to free trade, Mr Abendroth, but the UK government and those who parroted the cruel myths of Brexiteer #sunny uplands#.Mr Abendroth suggests that the fishing industry merely sells into the domestic market as a replacement to EU trade, without thought to the timescales required to repurpose supply lines and create a viable home market # evenit could be done fishing businesses would already be bankrupt.Scotland’s economy and the living standards and opportunities of Scots have been thrown under the wheels of England’s red Brexit bus. Never have the consequences of permitting Westminster to rule our country been more stark.But the time is coming when Scotland will have the historic opportunity to regain the huge benefits of EU membership and become a normal, thriving, independent state at the heart of Europe. There is an empty seat at the top table in Europe # and it won’t be empty for long.Ron Wilson, secretary, Kintyre SNP.Remember the closing stages of the Brexit negotiations  Boris Johnson pretended he was holding out to get the best deal for fishermen. In the end he agreed a deal that the Scottish Fishermen’s Federation described as #desperately poor# and #the worst of both worlds#.Fishermen are restricted to catch fewer fish in most key species. Lorries carrying stocks that have been caught were left to sit at Larkhall – unable to penetrate the new fog of bureaucracy. Scottish fishermen are forced to land the fish they can catch in Denmark – grim news for Scottish fish processors.Instead of trying to fix the problem, Tory Minister Jacob Rees-Mogg says the fish are happier to be British. Of course they are – the fishermen aren’t catching them.The Tories must sort out this mess they have created. Our fishermen and fish processing workers deserve better than silly remarks about happy fish.Councillor Alan Reid, Cowal ward.Keith Abendroth is spot on with his call for the fishing industry in Campbeltown to supply the home market.During my three-and-a-half years in the town it was possible to buy directly from the boat on occasion but it was nigh on impossible to buy fresh live lobster in the town#s fish shop.When I was new to the town , I experienced some shocking service at the some of the small retailers who I always endeavour to support. It is easier to get a full range of seafood and fish in Peebles, about  miles from the sea, which has an excellent fish shop supplied from Eyemouth on the East Coast.Much Welsh shellfish is sent by air to Europe. I often wondered why lorries trundled from Campbeltown across the Rest and Be Thankful and all the way to the English Channel crossings.Much of the st century supply chain is a mystery to me. For instance, much Pacic wild salmon is processed in China before being exported to the UK.  It is an excellent alternative to the farmed version at roughly the same price.Surely a town with an airport could develop a sea product freight service or is it simply down to volume, weight and cost Mark Davey, Peebles.Two weeks ago, at Campbeltown Free Church, we received a letter of thanks from Blythswood Care for filling shoeboxes to support the  Shoe Box Appeal.However, we are aware that many who contributed do not belong to Campbeltown Free Church.So, through the pages of the Courier, can I thank them for their kindness towards people they have never met but whose lives have been enriched by their generosity Dr Rodger M Crooks, Campbeltown Free Church minister.Like many, many other residents in Argyll and Bute I have received through the post a bizarre leaflet from the Liberal Democrats. Bizarre, because it promotes a candidate standing in a completely dferent seat # Caithness, Sutherland and Ross.Meanwhile, the good folk of Caithness, Sutherland and Ross have been equally mystied as to why the hapless Lib Dems have sent them leaflets promoting a candidate in Argyll and Bute!The Lib Dems have certainly lost their way when it comes to their policy on the EU # but it seems that they#ve lost their way in Scotland too.Les Wilson, Islay.Earlier this month the Prime Minister announced a third national lockdown. Although necessary, these measures mean many of our veterans will be facing the next several weeks – or months – completely alone.And while the vaccine rollout out across the country provides some hope, social isolation and loneliness poses a real threat to our elderly this winter, among them many former RAF personnel and their partners supported by the fund.To help combat this, last year the RAF Benevolent Fund introduced a weekly Check and Chat service to support members of the RAF Family experiencing loneliness. I speak to one such gentleman every Tuesday. He lives alone and spent much of  totally isolated and, for him, this service truly is a leline. We chat about what he’s been up to, what he’s cooking for tea, to his time in the RAF and often I’m the only person he will speak to for days.The fund also organises weekly telephone friendship groups, provides access to a listening and counselling service, relationship counselling support, and an online wellbeing portal to help support emotional wellbeing amongst the veteran community.Throughout the pandemic, many of us have learnt more about our neighbours and local community. That’s why we are calling on the people of Scotland to consider whether they know any RAF veterans, or their spouses or widows, who may be experiencing loneliness.To refer someone to the RAF Benevolent Fund, please visit rafbf.org or call   .Air Vice-Marshal Chris Elliot, chief executive, RAF Benevolent Fund.

title: new wildlife officer sets out priorities
story: Susan WindramUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  At the start of the pandemic in March we took the decision to make online access to our news free of charge by taking down our paywall. At a time where accurate information about Covid- was vital to our community, this was the right decision # even though it meant a drop in our income. In order to help safeguard the future of our journalism, the time has now come to reinstate our paywall.However, rest assured that access to all Covid related news will still remain free.To access all other news will require a subscription, as it did pre-pandemic.The good news is that for the whole of December we will be running a special discounted offer to get  months access for the price of one month. Thank you for supporting us during this incredibly challenging time.As the Investigative Support Officer for Scotland for the National Wildle Crime Unit , PC Gavin Ross will be a source of expertise in wildle crime at both the local and national level. He will work with inidual police wildle liaison officers, NGOs, the Scottish Government, NatureScot, RSPB, the SSPCA and Scottish Land and Estates. The position is funded by NatureScot.PC Ross was the community police officer for Dunbar, and has  years of police service and an extensive background in wildle crime issues, community policing, problem solving and educational work.Minister for Rural Affairs and the Natural Environment Ben Macpherson MSP said: #Wildle crime is despicable and tackling it has been a long-standing priority for the Scottish Government.#We work closely with a number of agencies to ensure perpetrators are brought to justice.#The Animals and Wildle Act, which recently became law, increases the maximum penalties for the most serious wildle crimes and extends the time available to Police Scotland to investigate.#The work of the National Wildle Crime Unit is hugely valued by communities across Scotland and we are committed to supporting it. I look forward to working with PC Ross in the future and congratulate him on his new role.#PC Ross said: #When I was in Edinburgh, very early in my service, I became involved in investigating wildle crime because of my interest and experience in this area. I’ve been a part-time wildle crime officer throughout my whole service and the new job is the pinnacle of my career.#I worked very hard preparing for my interview and was very keen to secure the job, which is a dream post. I am looking forward to settling into the role and working with all the dferent partner agencies which are so important in the fight against wildle crime.#In the six weeks I’ve been in post I’ve concentrated on meeting many of the partner agencies we work with in wildle crime. Unfortunately most of the meetings have had to be done virtually, but I feel they have all been really positive and I look forward to building on these initial foundations, especially when we can meet face to face.#The head of the NWCU, Chief Inspector Hubble added: #I was extremely pleased when PC Ross was successfully appointed as our new Scottish ISO and I am sure he is going to be a valuable asset to policing wildle crime.#Andy Turner, NatureScot wildle crime officer, said: #Eliminating wildle crime is huge priority for us, which is why we’ve provided funding for this post since . Wildle crime doesn’t just cause irreparable damage to Scotland’s nature, it also affects tourism, which in turn impacts on the economy.#We are committed to working with NWCU, Police Scotland and other members of the Partnership for Action Against Wildle Crimeto tackle this challenging issue.#We worked closely with Gavin’s predecessor, Charlie Everitt, to prevent wildle crime and raise awareness. I look forward to continuing to this important work with Gavin and the NWCU in the future.#NWCU’s main role is to assist in the prevention and detection of wildle crime by obtaining and distributing information from a wide range of organisations and by helping police forces investigate wildle crimes. NWCU also produce analysis which highlights local or national threats.The appointment of PC Ross comes after the retirement of PC Charlie Everitt, who had spent the last  years developing the role of Scottish ISO within the National Wildle Crime Unit.PC Everitt furthered countless operations, provided expert advice to police wildle liaison officers and acted as the key central point of contact between the police and a vast range of partner agencies.He was well known throughout the Scottish wildle crime arena and his professional knowledge, enthusiasm, and willingness to assist were beyond question. PC Ross recognised he had #big shoes to fill#.

Thank you for supporting us during this incredibly challenging time.Councillor Kieron Green extended thanks to residents of Argyll and Bute for helping to ensure it has continued to have low case numbers.But Jean Boardman, non-executive director with NHS Highland, asked whether communication will go out asking that even after receiving the vaccine, people continue to observe the rules.The discussion took place at a recent meeting of the area’s health and social care partnership’sintegration joint board , of which Councillor Green is chair.He said: #Thanks to the population of Argyll and Bute for the fact that we have relatively low levels of infection, which is not down to chance. The pressure on staff is high enough.#Following restrictions obviously has to continue.#The Covid-related discussion at the meeting opened with Dr Nicola Schinaia speaking to a report on the latest situation and case numbers.Ms Boardman then asked: #Are there plans, locally and nationally, to highlight to people that they cannot relax observation of rules once they receive the vaccine #We are hearing reports that people mistakenly think that they no longer need to observe the rules [once they have been vaccinated].#Dr Schinaia responded: #Yes, there are. title: tranent-juniors-knocked-scottish-cup-east-fife
story: The Belters, who had twice beaten teams from a higher league to reach the second round in their debut in the historic competition, dared to dream of an even more famous triumph after taking a third-minute lead at the Bayview Stadium courtesy of a long-range Steven Thomson free-kick.Tranent looked set to hold their lead until half-time against the Fers ndash who play three isions above them in Scottish League One ndash only to be stung by two goals just before the break from Scott Agnew and Craig Watson, turning a - lead into a - deficit.And two quickfire second-half goals from Agnew to complete his hat-trick ended Tranents hopes of reaching the third round, with Kevin Smith adding some extra gloss to make the final score - to East Fe.

title: east-lothians-football-clubs-see-remaining-january-matches-postponed
story: Concerns about the ldquoescalating coronavirus situation have seen football from below the Scottish Professional Football LeagueChampionship down, including the East of Scotland Football League , postponed for the rest of January.The Scottish Football Associationboard met on Sunday to discuss the pandemic "and its impact on the national game at all levels".A statement on the governing bodys website said: ldquoFollowing a meeting between the Scottish FA and the Minister for Public Health Sport and Wellbeing, both parties have agreed to impose a temporary suspension of all football beneath the Scottish Professional Football League Championship, encompassing all predominantly part-time tiers of the Scottish professional pyramid, from midnight tonight.ldquoThe impacted leagues are: SPFL League One, SPFL League Two, Scottish Womenrsquos Football Premier Leagues   , Highland League, Lowland League, East, West  South of Scotland Leagues, Scottish Junior FA Leagues and the North Caledonian League.Tranent Juniors were the only East Lothian team in action over the weekend as their Scottish Cup adventure came to an end at East Fe.The Belters, who sit top of the EOSFL Premier Division, were due to face Dundonald Bluebell this weekend but no games will now take place until February  at the earliest.Fellow Premier Division sides Musselburgh Athletic and Dunbar United were due to face Sauchie and Crossgates respectively this weekend, while Ormiston were due to welcome Kirkcaldy and Dysart, and Haddington Athletic were facing St Andrews in the First Division Conference A.Preston Athletic were not scheduled to have a game this weekend.However, those games will all now need to be rescheduled.Rod Petrie, Scottish FA president, said: ldquoThe Scottish FA is well aware of the efforts all clubs take to comply with the exacting protocols that were conditional on elite football being given an exemption to continue amid the pandemic.ldquoNonetheless, the continuation of football at all levels has weighed increasingly heavy on me as president, my colleagues on the board and the joint response group as we have watched the new strain of the virus spread rapidly.ldquoWhile national sport has been afforded the privilege of elite sporting exemption, the risk of mass transportation of untested, largely part-time players is something that cannot be sustained as the cases continue to rise and available hospital beds become increasingly scarce.ldquoAfter discussions with the SPFL, the Premiership and Championship will continue on the proviso that both adhere to the existing testing regime.ldquoThe vast majority of teams in those isions are full-time professional clubs and so the risk of transmission remains manageably low.ldquoThe cost implications to lower-ision clubs was one factor but so too the realisation that many ndash with some notable exceptions ndash consist of part-time players who are either prevented from working due to the virus or have to work.ldquoIn either case, the risk is currently too great amid the developing nationwide spread of the virus.

title: letter-week-new-super-school-prestonpans-blindwells
story: Under the local plan, construction of a new secondary school is already scheduled to cope with the later stages of the Blindwells development.Pending this new school being built, I imagine unsightly and unsatisfactory Portakabins will be added onto the already dilapidated Preston Lodge building, overcrowding its school hall and other facilities.Would it not be far better to establish a new purpose-built super school, which would be able to cope with the combined school populations of both the Blindwells and Prestonpans areas, and also to start building this much earlier than currently envisaged I recently suggested this idea with a local councillor. While he liked the concept in principle, he indicated that the current agreement with the Blindwells developer meant that the council would not be able to afford going ahead with such a project.This is because the developer is not obliged to produce any funds for a secondary school at Blindwells until a much later stage in the projectrsquos development.However, I have read recently in the Courier of least one instance ndash the postponing of improved access roads ndash where the council appears prepared to be bending over backwards to accommodate changes in the Blindwells development plan to suit the developer. Would it not be reasonable for the council to ask the developerthey might now reciprocate, by acceleratingtheir contribution to the arearsquos school estate Building a new secondary lsquosuper schoolrsquo earlier than now planned would substantially enhance the sales value of the new houses in the first stages of the Blindwells development, as well as provide a better pupil experience for everyone in the Prestonpans cluster.Angus TullochLongniddry

title: date-announced-opening-drive-through-covid-vaccination-centre-queen-margaret-university
story: It will have  stations and be capable of vaccinating , people a week.Other large centres in Edinburgh and West Lothian will begin vaccinating patients on Monday as part of wave two of the national vaccination programme.These include the Edinburgh International Conference Centre , which will be capable of vaccinating more than , people a week.East Lothian Community Hospital, in Haddington, has also been named as a smaller, more localised vaccination centre, along with many other community hubs in Edinburgh, Midlothian and West Lothian.David Small, of NHS Lothian, said they had already vaccinated "the vast majority of the first cohort to be prioritised" in the Lothians."GP practices continue to deliver the injections as fast as their vaccine supplies allow," he said.ldquoThis is a signicant moment as we embark on wave two of the largest vaccination programme that has ever been undertaken.ldquoWe need to vaccinate as many people as we possibly can to help save lives and provide protection to help communities get back to normal."We therefore urge people to attend their appointment once they are notied of the details."NHS Lothian has been working with councils, health and social care partnerships and other partners in recent weeks to ensure the sites are ready.The centres are the first of a total of  to be rolled out across Lothian, including the community hospital in Haddington.People aged between - and those most clinically vulnerable will be given appointments to be vaccinated by their GP, while those aged between - and  to  will be invited into mass vaccination sites and smaller community venues for their injections.Patients are being urged to keep their first appointment in order to provide protection to as many people, as quickly as possible eventheir appointment venue may not be the one that is closest to where they live.Smaller community clinics will deliver vaccinations in the local area for people with complex needs or who, for other reasons, absolutely cannot and would not be expected to travel to a mass centre.If patients absolutely cannot keep the appointment they have been given, they are being asked to call the Covid- Vaccination Helpline on    to rearrange their appointment. If they are aged  and over, they should phone their GP practice to rearrange your appointment.

title: brunton-theatre-groups-heading-online
story: In March, , all youth and adult theatre groups were postponed due to the Covid- pandemic, and they went online.A spokesperson for the Musselburgh-based Brunton Theatre said: ldquoLike many other art forms, the classes went online, providing an opportunity for fun, interaction and creativity ndash a fantastic tonic to trying times.Thanks to funding The Brunton Theatre Trust secured through Creative Scotland, the youth theatre network and Brunton Players are able to continue online programmes this year, with classes being offered for a low fee.The sessions will recommence online from Monday, February  and run for eight weeks, continuing through the February school break.All classes are led by experienced and qualied drama professionals.This term, some of the ELYT groups will be working with Wonder Fools, a charity and theatre company, on its lsquoPositive Stories For Negative Timesrsquo project.Wonder Fools has commissioned five plays by UK writers, which have been made available online for community theatre, charity and youth groups to perform.The company also provides a framework about how to rehearse, direct and record the works. The final performances will be filmed and uploaded to the internet, alongside all other performances made as part of this project, where they will be free to view.The Brunton spokesperson said feedback for the online youth theatre classes has been very positive.Brunton Players is a community theatre group for adults and usually meets weekly at The Brunton, with performances on stage at the Musselburgh venue.Now, participants are enjoying being creative together and practising performance skills online, with weekly workshops.The spokesperson added: ldquoThis is a great way to combat isolation and use creativity to have fun. New members are very welcome no previous experience is required.More information is available at www.thebrunton or contact youththeatre@eastlothian.gov.uk

title: driver-slammed-touring-north-coast-500-lockdown
story: Adam Jarguz posted on a social media site for owners of the Seat Leon MK car that he had made the three-day road trip last week.Alongside pictures he had taken on his journey was a caption that read ldquoNC complete.He added that he camped on the route, as hotels and BBs were closed, and did not encounter anyone during the trip, using pay-at-pump services for fuel.Under current Scottish Government lockdown restrictions, it is against the law to leave your home for anything other than an essential reason, with people urged to avoid unnecessary travel.Mr Jarguz has been criticised by members of the public who live along the route and by the North Coast  Ltd company.Tom Campbell, executive chairman of North Coast  Ltd, said: ldquoWe strongly condemn any irresponsible or anti-social behaviour conducted by a minority of visitors on the NC and would urge people always to report such behaviour to Police Scotland and other relevant authorities in the first instance.Margaret Meek, co-founder of NC The Land Weeps social media page, said: ldquoItrsquos not a grey area:itrsquos illegal to go from East Lothianto the Highlands for a jaunt for non-essential travel.ldquoObviously he did not drive  miles on a round trip and not get out of his car. Itrsquos not rocket science.Ali Gillespie, from Inverness, who spotted the social media post, said: ldquoYou only need to look at whatrsquos happening in Barra to see what happens when Covid arrives in wee places where locals arenrsquot expecting it.ldquoSelfish in the extreme.Mr Jarguz could not be reached for comment.

title: cameron-susan-law-say-goodbye-gullanes-mallard-hotel
story: The Mallard, on the villagersquos East Links Road, has been owned and managed by husband-and-we Susan and Cameron Law since .It was previously owned by Susanrsquos parents, Iain and Flora Clark, who took the business over in , after running a restaurant in Pitlochry.Iain chose the hotelrsquos name after being inspired by the wildle in Aberlady Bay.Sadly, he died four years later but Flora, Susan and the rest of the family worked together to keep the business going.When Flora died in , Susan and Cameron took over The Mallard.Susan said: ldquoHotel le is quite challenging sometimes, but wersquove met lots and lots of great people over the years.ldquoIt is quite sad in these Covid times people have had to give up businesses for financial reasons but we are really lucky that that was not the case for us.ldquoMy dad always used to say lsquohospitality with informalityrsquo, which is what we strove to achieve. We will miss hotel le.The pair had always planned to retire at this time but hopes for a large party have been scuppered due to the pandemic.As well as enjoying time with family, friends, and a new grandchild who was born in December, Susan and Cameron will be kept busy by their many hobbies and interests.Susan is former chairman and current service co-ordinator at Muirfield Riding Therapy, receiving an MBE for her work there and Cameron is a member at North Berwick Golf Club. They also plan to travel, when lockdown restrictions allow.But first on the to-do list is househunting. Susan has lived on the hotelrsquos premises since her parents owned it, with Cameron moving in after their marriage in .The pair, who previously ran The Ugly Duckling cafe in the village, will not be moving far and plan to stay in East Lothian, a community they have grown to love.Susan called the ending ldquobittersweet, adding that ldquoit is really hard to pick out just one memory from the past -and-a-half years of her family running The Mallard.She said she would rather pay tribute to and thank all the customers, guests and staff who had been a huge part of their lives. She added: ldquoWe have not been able to say proper goodbyes to people, which is quite sad.ldquoSome of them have been coming to the hotel for over  years.ldquoIrsquove said to the new owners that I want to meet up with some of the guests and say goodbye properly.ldquoAmong the plans was a two-day open-door party to allow people to drop in and say farewell.ldquoWorking in a hotel is an all-consuming business so retirement will take some getting used to. I donrsquot want to become a couch potato though! I donrsquot feel old enough to retire at all.: Ambitious plans for village hotelPlans last year by Structured House Group to demolish and replace the hotel with a new -bedroomed version will not go ahead.The Mallard has now been sold to East Lothian-based company Watchman Inns the hotelrsquos name is being changed to The Watchman and it is currently undergoing a refurbishment, with hopes it will reopen in July.Susan said that, with the name change, it was like she was ldquotaking [The Mallard name] with them, adding that it would be ldquoin our hearts and memories.The lettering that spells out the hotelrsquos name on the front of the building have also been gted to Susan and Cameron.

title: grand-designs-experiment-north-berwick-high-street-refused
story: Architect Robin Sutherland came up with the Passivhaus build for his family after they bought property at  High Street, North Berwick.With the front of the property refurbished into a new shop front with offices for the architect upstairs , he turned his attention to designing a family home on the strip of land behind it, which measures . metres long and . metres wide.Plans showed the ground floor having a bathroom and study bedroom, with parking bays at the front and a courtyard garden at the rear a bedroom, kitchen diner and outside roof terrace on the first floor and, on the second floor, a living room and bedroom.However, despite his design being described by one councillor as ldquoextraordinary, his vision for his new home clashed with neighbours, the community council and ward councillors, who claimed it went against the arearsquos conservation status.And despite planning officers ruling that the proposed house met its policies, the planning committee refused planning permission by six votes to five.Mr Sutherlandrsquos proposed home would have had room widths of . metres.In his design statement to planners, he said: ldquoThe site is very narrow, with a width of approximately . metres however, an internal room width of .m is achievable, which is comfortably within the bounds of normally scaled domestic space.But Councillor Jane Henderson, ward member, told the committee that the width of the home would be ldquonot much wider than a shipping container, my goodness gracious.She said: ldquoI am not convinced this is the best place for a Grand Designs experiment, adding: ldquoJust because theoretically it can be done does not make it right.Grand Designs is a popular and long-running home improvements TV show where unique and daringly designed homes are built.Neighbours overlooking the proposed house had objections about the impact of the three-storey home on their privacy, in particular a proposed roof terrace. And they raised concerns about the use of zinccladding on the walls and roo.Mr Sutherland highlighted other properties in North Berwick which had zinc cladding Councillor Jim Goodfellow, ward member, described the proposed new house as a ldquozinc house.North Berwick Community Council also lodged objections, citing the impact of the zinc materials on the conservation area and on neighboursrsquo privacy and amenity.Councillor Norman Hampshire, planning convenor, backed the proposals, highlighting that planning officers had ruled the design met the councilrsquos relevant planning policies.He said the house was something which would, in time, be viewed as an ldquoattractive addition to the townrsquos conservation area.FAREWELL: Hotel owners check out after familys near  years in businessHowever, Councillor Willie Innes, council leader, pointed to the strength of concerns from the community and said that while he appreciated the ldquoextraordinary way the architect had created the design for the house, it was in the wrong location.He said: ldquoI accept what local members are saying. I think the overall impact would be too signicant.The committee voted by six members to five to refuse planning permission.Mr Sutherland declined to comment following the decision.

title: steeplejacks-tackle-maintenance-st-michaels-church
story: The specialist team completed an inspection of the lightning conductors and steeple, removed vegetation and also carried out work on an opening where coverings had fallen inwards.The project was undertaken by Northern Steeplejacks, which is based at Newtongrange in Midlothian.The cockerel weathervane was refurbished under a previous contract.There has been a church on the site since the th century.The present church was built in  to the design of Robert Nisbet and the steeple is recorded as being by the architect William Sibbald, following his earlier design for that at St Andrewrsquos, George Street, Edinburgh, in .This project was to a large extent the brainchild of the illustrious minister of St Michaelrsquos, Dr Alexander lsquoJupiterrsquo Carlyle.The kirk stands on the site of a Roman praetorium and replaces a medieval church. It has an Adam-style ceiling and stained glass.The building was substantially altered to accommodate the innovative new trend in worship ndash a pipe organ ndash in . This Lewis organ was quite radical in its design at that time.St Michaelrsquos boasts some notable ministers in its post-Reformation history, such as the second minister, The Rev Andrew Blackhall, who was an accomplished composer of music.The Rev Alexander Carlyle was a pioneer of the Sunday School movement and his autobiography shed light on a turbulent period in Scotlandrsquos history.The Rev John Beveridge was a campaigner for the renewal of worship and distinguished himself by his devotion to duty during a cholera outbreak.In , St Michaelrsquos celebrated the th anniversary of the present building, which is listed lsquoCategory Arsquo, meaning it is of special architectural or historical interest and is an outstanding example of a particular period, style or building type.

title: weekend-coronavirus-vaccine-clinic-set-riverside-medical-practice
story: They will be invited to attend on Saturday to receive their jabs from GP partner Dr Catherine Cameron, nurses Diane Fyffe, Delia Marriott, Sarah Falconer and Gillian Fulton, and general practice paramedic Tracy Henry.Almost  per cent of the first priority group have been vaccinated already and, while Riverside and other GP practices across the country are still constrained by vaccine supply, the third vaccine allocation sent to Riverside was large enough to warrant a weekend clinic.Staff will soon start to vaccinate people aged - and those in the shielding group who are defined on medical grounds as extremely vulnerable from Covid-.The practice, based at Musselburgh Primary Care Centre, is the largest in East Lothian and one of the biggest in Scotland, with about , patients.Dr Joanna Stenke, GP partner, said: ldquoOur dedicated team are delighted to be coming into the practice at the weekend to get as many of the first priority group vaccinated as possible.ldquoGPs across Scotland were asked by the Scottish Government to vaccinate registered patients aged  and over who can attend the clinic in person and wersquore pleased to have been able to vaccinate  of this group already at Riverside. Most people have been delighted when wersquove phoned to offer an appointment, and we really enjoy making the call.She added: ldquoThis weekend clinic will see the majority of our remaining patients aged  and over vaccinated, with the remaining few to be vaccinated when we receive our next vaccine allocation.ldquoWersquoll then begin to offer vaccine appointments to registered patients aged - who can attend the clinic in person along with shielders of all ages. Shielders are defined as those who have already received a shielders letter from the government or their GP.Eligible patients will be contacted by phone by the team at Riverside. Patients should wait to be contacted to help the team get the vaccines out to patients as soon as possible.The next priority group, those aged - years, will also start to be vaccinated shortly - but this is currently planned to take place in mass vaccination venues and health board clinics rather than in GP surgeries.Queen Margaret University has been named as a mass vaccination venue.Local health board teams will vaccinate housebound registered patients and these patients should wait to be contacted by them direct.For more information about the vaccination programme at Riverside, including which vaccine is being used and a weekly update on numbers vaccinated, visit www.theriversidepractice covid--vaccination-underway-at-riversidePatients are being advised to continue to follow local and national restrictions after receiving the vaccine.A spokesperson for the East Lothian Health and Social Care Partnership said: ldquoI can say that the vaccination programme in East Lothian is progressing well, in line with the planned national roll-out.But East Lothian MSP Iain Gray has described the speed of the Covid- vaccine rollout in East Lothian as a whole as ldquounacceptable.: Speed of Covid vaccine rollout labelled lsquounacceptablersquoThe latest figures show that , people had been vaccinated across the county up to Sunday, January  ndash . per cent of the countyrsquos population. This placed East Lothian as the third slowest council area in Scotland for vaccines being administered.John Swinney MSP, Deputy First Minister, insisted this week that the national vaccination programme was on track.He said: ldquoGood progress has been made on the delivery of the vaccine for over-s. We have got to  per cent of care home residents, who are most at risk of morbidity from Covid.ldquoWe are in a majority now in over-s and that task will be completed by the end of the first week in February.

title: stuart-rollo-wins-porsche-macan-gts-70-000-botb-competition
story: Competition winner Stuart Rollo, of Prestonpans, received the surprise of a letime when he was told he would be taking home a Porsche Macan GTS, worth about pound,.But his day got even better when he was then informed that pound, would be coming his way too.His online ticket cost just pound.The -year-old was celebrating after receiving a video call from Virgin Radio UK presenter Christian Williams that he had won the prizes in BOTBrsquos long-running Dream Car Competition.Stuart said: ldquoThis is crazy. It was all about the car for me but this is just the cherry on top.This money will go such a long way for us.ldquoItrsquos been a tricky year for everyone and Irsquom really fortunate to still be working but we as a family need something to look forward to.ldquoThe kids have always talked about going to America so maybe a big family holiday is on the cards.BOTB hands over the keys to two cars each week, as well as a lestyle prize. Other recent winners have bagged a quad bike, a holiday to Las Vegas and a gaming tech bundle.The company, listed on the stockmarket, was founded by William Hindmarch in  and has given away more than poundmillion worth of cars so far.Competition entrants select what luxury car they would like to take home, pay a small entry fee and then make an online lsquospot the ballrsquo selection which determines who wins.Christian, who surprises BOTB winners, said: ldquoStuart seems like such a lovely guy and Irsquom super happy for him.ldquoHersquos played for this car so many times and what a fantastic prize it is.ldquoPlus, the pound, cash is definitely going to come in handy ndash he could even buy another Porschehe wanted to!ldquoMassive congratulations again, Stuart!

title: bogus-john-knoxs-house-haddington
story: According to a paper by the local historian J.H. Jamieson, in the third volume of the East Lothian Antiquarian and Field Naturalistsrsquo Society, the house on the eastern side of the Gfordgate pointed out as Knoxrsquos birthplace was demolished prior to .In , none less than celebrated essayist and historian Thomas Carlyle made sure that an oak was planted and a memorial stone erected on the site this oak still remains today and is quite a majestic tree.It is a mysterious matter that there was a lsquoJohn Knoxrsquos Housersquo in Haddington in Edwardian times, the subject of several picture postcards, including one by the notable North Berwick artist Reginald Phillimore.The truth appears to be, according to the Jamieson article, that another house, situated on the western side of the Gfordgate, was pointed out to the tourists as the birthplace of John Knox, although it only dated back to the th century.The mischievous locals received generous tips from the gullible tourists, who had come from Edinburgh and beyond to see the great Reformerrsquos birthplace.A rustic-looking building, this bogus lsquoKnoxrsquos Housersquo, was still standing as recently as the s, but it does not remain today.It is curious that Knoxrsquos birthplace is not definitely known, with some historians advocating the villages of Gford or Morham the house in Edinburgh pointed out as lsquoJohn Knoxrsquos Housersquo was never inhabited by the Reformer, but was named from an obscure popular tradition arising in the early th century nor is the exact site of Knoxrsquos grave known, although a plaque is said to mark it in what is today the car park in Parliament Square.

title: gardening-column-succulents-cacti
story: In this column wersquore looking at succulents and cacti ndash a group of indoor plants that are so easy that theyrsquoreimpossible to get wrong.Succulents and cacti tend to be grouped together because they can store water in their tissues that enables them to survive hot, dry conditions. This adaptation means that they are ideally suited to being houseplants, particularly in homes where the owners are forgetful waterers!Succulent is a general description for plants that have tissues adapted to store water but doesnrsquot refer to a specic plant. On the other hand, cactus is a botanical name for plants belonging to the plant family Cactaceae and, for specic physiological reasons, may not always be regarded as succulents.Succulent suggestionsAmongst the toughest, most robust indoor succulents is the sanseveria, a wide range of plants whose common names include mother-in-lawrsquos tongue , snake plantand birds nest plant .With bold, thick, simple leaves, theyrsquore almost sculptural in appearance, tolerant of low light levels and, because they require minimal attention, theyrsquore an obvious choice for those with little or no experience of houseplants.Sanseveria are particularly good at improving the indoor air quality theyrsquore known to remove air pollutants including formaldehyde, xylene and toluene and, because they convert carbon dioxide to oxygen at night, theyrsquore popular bedroom plants.Another group of plants that are particularly easy to care for are the aloes, which the ancient Egyptians called lsquoimmortality plantsrsquo because they are almost indestructible.The natural healing benefits of aloe vera has made it popular for centuries and is iously credited with the ability to soothe irritated or burned skin, improve skin, hair, oral hygiene and digestion and to treat acne and arthritis.Like sanseveria, aloe requires very little care, tolerates low light levels and infrequent watering, removes air-borne pollutants and oxygenates the air at night, which aids sleep.One of our favourite succulents is the echiveria, which grows in compact rosettes of succulent, sometimes coloured leaves from which flowering stalks may grow.These plants like a reasonable amount of light, some dilute feed when actively growing and prefer under-watering to over-watering. A happy echiveria will produce little plantlets which can be removed and grown into new plants.Carefree cactusIt would be impossible to talk about easy-to-care for plants without mentioning cacti, which have well-developed survival adaptations.Most cacti have developed spines which in fact are highly modied leaves. Not only do these spines help prevent the plant being grazed, but they also reduce the airflow around the plant, which helps it conserve water.Photosynthesis takes place on the stemand its shallow, far-reaching root system enables the cactus to react quickly and absorb any water reaching the ground.Whilst the enormous tree-like cacti of the American desert may be the first cactus that springs to mind, wersquove highlighted some interesting houseplant types below that are incredibly easy to look after and certainly wonrsquot take over your home!There are many dferent shapes of cacti, including round, flat, columnar, smooth, bumpy, ribbed and fluted, and itrsquos important to note that some of these actually change shape depending on how much water is stored in the stem at the time!Not all cacti have fully developed spines. For example, the popular schlumbergera, of which the best-known culti is the Christmas-flowering cactus, has less modied leaves which look like lsquoteethrsquo along the edge of their stems. Their stems grow in lsquosegmentsrsquo and resemble flattened pads, with their flowers being produced at the end of the segments.Although the Christmas-flowering culti is most popular in the UK, there are dferent cultis which flower at dferent times of the year.In their natural habitat, schlumbergera grow on trees or in rocks and generally enjoy shady habitats with high humidity, making them an ideal choice for bathrooms.If yoursquore looking for an unusual and interesting but easy-to-care-for indoor hanging plant, you might consider the aporocactus ndash a group of tree-growing cactus that grow well in a hanging pot.For a cactus with impact, the gymnocalycium mihanovichii is a sure winner. The top part of the stem on this cactus lacks green pigmentand can be bright red, yellow or other amazing colours.So,yoursquore looking for a plant that thrives on neglect, hopefully wersquove given you some ideas!Just remember that the golden rule for cacti and succulents is to under-water rather than over-water ndash too much moisture will cause disease and rot.For more information, take a look on our website at www.merryhatton

title: mary-contini-column-food-thought-covid
story: To be able to buy vegetables from the likes of Crunchy Carrot in Dunbar or Phantassie in East Linton is my foodie heaven !It is probably more expensive to shop locally and, as you need to drive to dferent outlets, it does take longer.For hard-pressed working families, this is not always an option. A big supermarket shop, with selections of everything we need, is a necessary part of most householdsrsquo routine.This year, however, this never-ending choice and supply has clearly been disrupted. The perfect storm of pandemic, Brexit and bad weather has resulted in frequently empty shelves. Some products are unavailable.Prices are increasing. Recent reports of supermarkets recalling food ranges such as pre-prepared seafoods and cheese spreads because of risk of contamination indicate trouble in the system.The food journey to supermarket shelf is long. Ingredients are pulled together from multiple counties, even countries.The brilliant exercise in sourcing, logistics, and extending the le of ingredients has successfully given us the lsquowhat you want when you fancy itrsquo way of le we have become used to.But, having been forced to stop and reassess how we shop, eat and live, I suspect many families are keen to step back from this corporate sales pitch and rediscover the local delights on our doorstep.Steady queues at the doors of local food shops, increased numbers of local food delivery services and fish vans bringing an ever-increasing selection of fish from the pier to our kitchen sink is, to my mind, a positive outcome of a dreadful situation.Milk daily on the doorstep. Lucarsquos ice cream straight to the door.Whatrsquos not to like

title: east-lothian-peeps-past-january-26-29-1996-1971-1921

they arrived in Aberlady to stamp their mark on village le.The Searles, from Glamis in Angus, have taken over the local Post Office from the previous owners of three years, Derek and Gloria Hutchinson ndash who now plan to travel the globe.The Hutchinsons are taking early retirement as they both near  and aim to start their voyage in America, and work their way from West to East, dropping in on friends who are scattered around the world.But the couple want a home base toto and are searching for a house in Aberlady or Gullane before they start their adventures abroad.Derek is a Geordie who
